content.text: Once upon a time, there was a kind shoemaker who lived in a little house at the edge of a village. He was a good man, but he was very poor.
He had only enough leather left to make one last pair of shoes. Sadly, he cut out the pieces one evening, laid them on his workbench, and said to his wife, "Tomorrow, I shall stitch these together
and see if I can sell them. If I cannot, then I do not know what we shall do." With a heavy heart, the shoemaker went to bed.
The next morning, when he came down to his workshop, he could hardly believe his eyes. There, on his workbench, stood the most beautiful pair of shoes he had ever seen—perfectly stitched, polished,
and ready to wear. He picked them up in amazement. "Who could have made these?" he wondered aloud. Just then, a nobleman passed by the shop and saw the shoes in the window.
He stepped inside at once. "These are the finest shoes I have ever seen!" he exclaimed. "I must have them!" He paid the shoemaker far more than they were worth, and the shoemaker was
overjoyed. With the money, he bought enough leather to make two more pairs of shoes. That night, he cut out the pieces for two pairs and left them on the workbench.
"Perhaps," he said to his wife, "we shall have good fortune again." And with that, they went to bed. The next morning, the shoemaker and his wife found not one, but *two* pairs of shoes on the
workbench—each one more exquisite than the last. A wealthy merchant saw them in the window and bought both pairs at once, paying even more than the nobleman had.
Now the shoemaker had enough money to buy leather for *four* pairs of shoes. Night after night, the same thing happened.
The shoemaker would cut out the pieces, leave them on the bench, and in the morning, find the most wonderful shoes he had ever seen.
Soon, his shop became famous throughout the land, and he grew quite wealthy. But he and his wife could not understand who was helping them.
One evening, the shoemaker said to his wife, "Let us stay awake tonight and see who is making these shoes. It must be some kind soul who wishes to help us."
So they hid behind a curtain in the workshop and waited. As the clock struck midnight, something magical happened. Two tiny elves, no bigger than a child’s hand, crept into the room.
They were dressed in rags, their little feet bare and cold. Without a word, they set to work. Their fingers moved so quickly that the shoemaker and his wife could scarcely follow them.
They stitched, they hammered, they polished—until all the shoes were made, and not a scrap of leather was left. When the elves finished, they vanished as quickly as they had come.
The shoemaker and his wife were filled with wonder and gratitude. "Those poor little creatures!" said the shoemaker’s wife. "They work so hard, and yet they have no shoes of their own.
We must do something to thank them." The next day, the shoemaker’s wife set to work. She cut out tiny pieces of soft leather and stitched them into the tiniest, most delicate shoes anyone had
ever seen. Meanwhile, the shoemaker made two little coats and two pairs of trousers from warm, fine cloth. That night, instead of leaving leather on the bench, they left the gifts for the elves.

When the elves arrived that midnight, they found the presents instead of the usual leather. At first, they were puzzled. Then, they saw the shoes, the coats, and the trousers—and their little faces lit up
with joy. They put on the clothes at once, dancing and laughing with delight. "Now we are dressed like fine gentlemen!" they cried. "We shall never be cold again!"
From that night on, the elves never returned to the shoemaker’s workshop. But the shoemaker and his wife did not mind, for they knew the elves were happy. And as for the shoemaker?
His business continued to thrive, and he and his wife lived comfortably for the rest of their days, always remembering the kindness of the little elves who had helped them in their time of need.
And so, my dear child, if you ever find yourself in need of a little magic, remember—kindness and gratitude can work wonders.
